awd_titl_txt: Zipping Towards STEM:  Integrating Engineering Design into the Middle School Physical Science Curriculum
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics through the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers program. It will integrate engineering design principles into Akron Public School district's curriculum unit on force and motion for 1800 underrepresented eighth grade students across 12 schools and 98 classrooms.  Students will be introduced to basic applied physics concepts in rigid-body dynamics where they will design, test, and redesign model stock mini-cars using computer assisted design software, 3D printers, and virtual and desk-top wind tunnels. To prepare students for this challenge, university-led summer institutes will provide all eighth grade science teachers with the knowledge, technical content, and technology experience needed to implement the integrated curriculum based on engineering practices. This step provides assurance that teachers can move students from the fundamental to the challenge level where students will seek a deeper understanding of engineering design principles. 

Graduate and senior-level aerospace systems engineering students and faculty members from the University of Akron and other local partners will help guide teachers and students through six basic tasks using model mini-cars. As students engage in the design and redesign process they will manipulate weight placement to maximize speed and use computer-based virtual wind tunnels to assess car performance in terms of drag coefficient. User-friendly graphical interface software will help students account for computational fluid dynamics and provide students with design performance metrics on drag and fluid flows through fog induced streamlines. Models for further testing will be produced using 3-D printers. Data collected will determine how well teachers and students move through the engineering design tasks. If the results show that teachers and students grasped the basic concepts that undergird engineering design, school district leaders have agreed to continue to use this model system wide to bring real-world experiences to eighth grade classrooms using engineering design to teach force and motion.

por.por_cntn:
Zipping to STEM was a four-year study integrating technology and engineering design into the eighth-grade science curriculum, guided by state and national science standards, and using a problem-based approach. The project?s aim was to expand access to authentic engineering activities to underrepresented populations, by integrating the program into the regular school science curriculum. Year 1 of the study focused on developing and piloting the teacher professional development and curriculum. In Years 2 ? 4, the impact of the curriculum was tested by comparing students in the intervention group each year to students in the same district who did not experience the curriculum in Year 2 of the study.

Students were presented with the problem to build and optimize a Soap Box Derby? Mini-Car under certain design constraints. They investigated the performance of various car shapes on a track and in a wind tunnel, and learned about engineering concepts such as prototyping and optimization. They applied previous knowledge of forces and motion and kinetic and potential energy to investigate the problem, and learned how to use Computer Aided Design (CAD) software. Working in teams, they designed a new car shell with CAD, imported their designs into the Wind Tunnel Simulator (project developed computer simulation), and using the testing results, they redesigned the car shells to optimize the performance. Successful designs were 3-D printed and tested by racing down the track and placing in a wind tunnel. A district wide competition was conducted to compare the performance of various designs. Students presented their work to university faculty and community representatives. They also explored careers in additive manufacturing. This approach allowed seamless integration of science, technology, and engineering disciplines, which showcased the relevance of science and mathematics to solving real world problems to increase students? interest and motivation to learn.

Fifteen teachers implemented the district-wide curriculum, resulting in approximately 3,000 students participating across the project period. Students in the intervention groups across Years 2-4 of the project had significantly higher post scores than the comparison group on measures of their understanding of engineering design concepts, application of the design process to a new design problem, and force and motion concepts. Students? overall career interest in STEM and attitudes toward STEM remained stable over time in both the intervention and comparison groups. In addition, students reported learning about teamwork, perseverance, and grit when working on an open ended design project. Teachers? self-efficacy for teaching engineering increased from before to after implementing the curriculum. Teachers implementing the curriculum over two or more years maintained their high level of self-efficacy in Year 4 of the study. The project?s success in building a sustainable curriculum and addressing implementation barriers (e.g., technology) is reflected in the participating district?s decision to adopt the curriculum in the following academic year after the project support was gradually released.

Five educational materials resulted from this project including the (1) Zipping to STEM Integrated Engineering Curriculum; (2) Zip to STEM Wind Tunnel Simulator (computer software); (3) Engineering Concept Assessment Modified for Eighth-Grade, (4) Scoring Rubric for the Engineering Concept Assessment Modified for the Eighth-Grade, and (5) Zip to STEM Manufacturing Video, showcasing additive manufacturing in Northeast Ohio.

To date, we presented at seven conferences and published four peer-reviewed works in the Journal of Applied Measurement, Science Scope, and Proceedings of the American Society for Engineering Education.  Additional anticipated publications of the project results include reports on the (1) impact of the intervention on student outcomes across three years, (2) development and validation of the Engineering Concept Assessment Modified for Eighth Grade (and rubric), (3) teachers? experiences and barriers in implementing the curriculum, and (4) research-practice partnership model for developing, implementing, and sustaining a district-wide curriculum. Three potential future directions of this research are to (1) secure funding to test the impact and develop solutions to technology barriers to implementation when scaled-up across other schools, (2) test the impact when transferred to rural setting, and (3) adapt the curriculum to include additional engineering design problems to increase student motivation in STEM.
